A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Does the concept of a/an Map/Function need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of a Ring Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To understand the concept of the image of a ring homomorphism, we need to first comprehend what a ring homomorphism is. A ring homomorphism is a specific type of function that preserves the ring operations (addition and multiplication) between two rings. The definition of the image of a ring homomorphism involves the set of all outputs of the ring homomorphism function from the domain ring $R$ to the codomain ring $R'$. This set, denoted as $\\[\operatorname{im} \\[varphi\\]$, is defined using the function $\\[varphi\\]$ applied to all elements of $R$. Therefore, the concept of a function or map is crucial because it forms the foundational mechanism through which elements of $R$ are associated with elements of $R'$ in a well-defined manner. Without the concept of a function or map, the notion of applying $\\[varphi\\]$ to elements of $R$ to form $\\[\operatorname{im} \\[varphi\\]$ would not make sense, as there would be no systematic way to associate elements between the two sets.
